title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
text:
Read Time: ~8 Minutes
As Data Scientists using Mac, Windows, or Linux, we live in two worlds. We deal with massive datasets (perfect for Cloud Storage) and version-dependent code (perfect for Git).
Deciding where to store a project can be confusing. Make the wrong choice, and you end up with corrupted repositories or lost versions. This guide breaks down exactly where your files belong.

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
section: 1. The Decision Matrix: What Goes Where?
text:
1. The Decision Matrix: What Goes Where?
The fundamental difference is simple: OneDrive syncs the ‚ÄúNow‚Äù (making folders identical across devices), while GitHub tracks the ‚ÄúHistory‚Äù (how a file evolved line-by-line).






Tipüß™ The ‚ÄúNotepad Test‚Äù (Rule of Thumb)



Open your file in a basic text editor (Notepad/TextEdit).

Can you read it? (Python script, Markdown, CSV) ‚Üí Use GitHub.
Does it look like alien gibberish? (PDF, Excel, .pkl, .exe) ‚Üí Use OneDrive.











Feature
OneDrive / Dropbox
GitHub / GitLab




Best For
Final Results, Documents, Images
Source Code, Configs, Text


File Types
Binary (.docx, .pdf, .jpg, .zip)
Plain Text (.py, .R, .md, .tex)


Data Size
Great for Large Data (>100MB)
Poor for large files (Keep repo < 1GB)


Conflict Handling
Creates ‚ÄúConflicted Copy‚Äù files
Manual line-by-line merge

text:
2. The ‚ÄúMirrored‚Äù Workflow (Recommended)
For research and data science, you shouldn‚Äôt choose one or the other. You need both, but they must remain separate.





flowchart LR
    Git["üíª Local Folder (Git)
    ~/Projects/analysis
    (Scripts, Reports, Configs)"] 
    
    Cloud["‚òÅÔ∏è Cloud Storage
    ~/OneDrive/Data
    (Raw CSVs, Large Zips, Final PDFs)"]

    Git <-->|"Linked via Code"| Cloud

    style Git stroke:#2563eb,stroke-width:2px,fill:#fff,color:#333
    style Cloud stroke:#f59e0b,stroke-width:2px,fill:#fff,color:#333







How to link them safely (Mac/Win/Linux safe)
Use code that detects your OS automatically so you don‚Äôt have to change paths when switching from Mac to Windows.
R Example:
# path.expand("~") finds C:/Users/Name (Win) or /Users/Name (Mac)
data_path <- file.path(path.expand("~"), "OneDrive", "Research", "data.csv")
df <- read.csv(data_path)
Python Example:
from pathlib import Path
import pandas as pd

# Path.home() is the universal way to find the user folder
data_path = Path.home() / "OneDrive" / "Research" / "data.csv"
df = pd.read_csv(data_path)

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
section: 3. The Danger Zone: Git INSIDE OneDrive
text:
3. The Danger Zone: Git INSIDE OneDrive






Important‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL WARNING



Never initialize a Git repository inside a synced OneDrive/Dropbox/iCloud folder.


Why? Sync clients (OneDrive) and Version Control (Git) fight over the hidden .git folder. This leads to:

Repo Corruption: OneDrive may ‚Äúsync‚Äù a file lock that Git needs.
Conflicted Copies: You will end up with files named script.py (Computer Name Conflicted Copy).

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
section: 4. How to Fix It (Moving Out of OneDrive)
text:
4. How to Fix It (Moving Out of OneDrive)
If your project is currently stuck in OneDrive, follow these steps. Do NOT move it to ‚ÄúDocuments‚Äù (as Documents often auto-syncs to Cloud too).

Step 0: Create a Safe ‚ÄúProjects‚Äù Folder

üçé macOS: Create /Users/name/Projects (Do not put in Documents!)
ü™ü Windows: Create C:\Users\name\Projects (Do not put in Documents!)
üêß Linux: Create /home/name/Projects (Safe anywhere in ~)



Step 1: On Your Primary Computer

Move the Folder: Drag your project folder OUT of OneDrive and into your new Projects folder.
Verify: Open your terminal (Git Bash on Windows).
cd ~/Projects/my-project
git status
Cleanup: Check OneDrive. If a copy remains there, delete it to stop the sync confusion.



Step 2: On Your Secondary Computer
Do not try to ‚Äúfix‚Äù the existing folder on your second computer. It‚Äôs faster to start fresh.

Let OneDrive Sync: Wait for OneDrive to update. It should automatically remove the old folder.
Clone Fresh: Download a clean connection to GitHub in your safe local folder.
cd ~/Projects
git clone https://github.com/yourname/my-project.git

title: Git vs.¬†OneDrive: The Data Scientist‚Äôs Guide
text:
Summary

Code lives in ~/Projects (Git).
Data lives in ~/OneDrive (Cloud).
Never put Git inside OneDrive or Documents (if synced).

title: Anscombe‚Äôs quartet
text:
So, I am learning how to use ggplot. Here is one my first attempts and at the same time I discover that you need to use the gridExtra package to layout multiople ggplots. I am using one of my favourite datasets: the Anscombe quartet

library(ggplot2)
library(grid)
library(gridExtra)

data(anscombe)

The quartet comprises four datasets that have nearly identical simple descriptive statistics, yet appear very different when graphed.

p1<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x1,y1))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(3,16)
p2<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x2,y2))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(3,16)
p3<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x3,y3))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(3,16)
p4<-ggplot(anscombe,aes(x4,y4))+geom_point()+geom_smooth(method="lm",se=FALSE,color="red")+xlim(7,20)

grid.arrange(p1,p2,p3,p4,ncol=2)

title: The Academic Workflow
text:
As academic data scientists, we juggle three distinct types of work: Teaching (slides, quizzes), Research (papers, heavy analysis), and Administration.
If you work across multiple machines‚Äîsay, a powerful Office Desktop and a personal Laptop‚Äîyou face a dilemma: Cloud storage (OneDrive/Dropbox) is great for PDFs but ruins code history. Git is perfect for code but chokes on 2GB datasets.
Here is the ‚ÄúMirrored Architecture‚Äù to handle it all effortlessly.

title: The Academic Workflow
section: 1. The Setup: Where to create your folders

title: The Academic Workflow
The Academic Workflow
section: 3. The Automation: One Script to Rule Them All
text:
3. The Automation: One Script to Rule Them All
When you have 10+ active repositories, you cannot manually git pull inside every folder. You need a ‚ÄúMaster Loop‚Äù script.
#!/bin/bash
# üíæ Save this as: sync_work.sh
# ---------------------------------------------------------
# Define where your Git Projects live (Not OneDrive paths!)
# ---------------------------------------------------------
TARGET_DIRS=(
    "$HOME/Projects/Teaching"
    "$HOME/Projects/Research"
)

echo "üîÑ MASTER SYNC INITIATED..."

# Function to handle a single repository
sync_repo() {
    local repo_path="$1"
    local name=$(basename "$repo_path")
    cd "$repo_path" || return

    # Check if it's actually a git repo
    if [ ! -d ".git" ]; then return; fi

    echo -e "\nüìÇ Processing: $name"

    # 1. ADD & COMMIT (Save your work)
    git add .
    if ! git diff-index --quiet HEAD --; then
        timestamp=$(date "+%Y-%m-%d %H:%M")
        git commit -m "Auto-Sync: $(hostname) at $timestamp" --quiet
        echo "   üíæ Local changes committed."
    fi

    # 2. PULL (Get work from other computers)
    # We use --rebase to keep history clean (linear)
    if git pull --rebase origin main --quiet; then
        echo "   ‚¨áÔ∏è  Pulled latest changes."
    else
        echo "   ‚ùå CONFLICT DETECTED. Please resolve manually."
        return 1
    fi

    # 3. PUSH (Upload your work)
    if git push origin main --quiet; then
        echo "   ‚¨ÜÔ∏è  Pushed to GitHub."
    else
        echo "   ‚ùå Push failed. Check internet connection."
    fi
}

# MAIN LOOP
# Find all subdirectories in your target folders and sync them
for parent in "${TARGET_DIRS[@]}"; do
    if [ -d "$parent" ]; then
        for d in "$parent"/*/; do
            sync_repo "${d%/}"
        done
    fi
done

echo -e "\nüéâ Sync Complete! Safe to switch computers."
Mac/Linux Users: Run chmod +x sync_work.sh to make it executable. Windows Users: Install ‚ÄúGit Bash‚Äù (included with Git for Windows) to run this script.

title: The Academic Workflow
section: 4. Connecting the Worlds: How to Load Data
text:
4. Connecting the Worlds: How to Load Data
Your code is in ~/Projects, but your data is in ~/OneDrive. How do you load the data without hardcoding paths that break when you switch computers?

Method A: For Small Data (Inside Git)
If your data is small (<50MB) and lives inside your project folder, use Project-Relative Paths. This guarantees your code runs anywhere.
Using R‚Äôs here package
library(here) 
# 'here()' automatically finds the root of your Git project
# No more setwd()! 
df <- read.csv(here("data", "small_dataset.csv"))
Using Python‚Äôs pyprojroot
import pandas as pd
from pyprojroot import here

# Finds the root containing .git, requirements.txt, etc.
# The '/' operator works because here() returns a Path object
data_path = here() / "data" / "small_dataset.csv"
df = pd.read_csv(data_path)


Method B: For Large Data (In OneDrive/Cloud)
For data that lives outside the project (in the cloud), paths might differ per machine (e.g., OneDrive - University vs OneDrive - Personal). The professional solution is Environment Variables.

Create a hidden file in your Home folder containing the path for that specific computer.

üìÑ .Renviron (Save in your Home folder)
# On your Work Computer
CLOUD_DATA_DIR="/Users/admin/OneDrive - University/Research"

# On your Home Computer
CLOUD_DATA_DIR="/Users/john/OneDrive/Research"

Load it in your code using the variable name. The code remains identical on both machines!

In R (Automatic Loading)
# R automatically reads .Renviron on startup
data_root <- Sys.getenv("CLOUD_DATA_DIR")

df <- read.csv(file.path(data_root, "climate_change_paper", "big_data.csv"))
In Python (Using dotenv)
import os
import pandas as pd
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load variables from .env or .Renviron file
load_dotenv() 

data_root = os.getenv("CLOUD_DATA_DIR")
df = pd.read_csv(f"{data_root}/climate_change_paper/big_data.csv")

title: The Academic Workflow
text:
Summary Checklist

Location: Move all code to ~/Projects. Move all docs to ~/OneDrive.
Structure: Keep separate folders for Teaching and Research inside both locations.
Automate: Run the sync script when you sit down (Pull) and when you stand up (Push).
Paths: Use here() for repo files and Sys.getenv() for cloud files.
